less indifferent. We should, at any
rate, have no preferences, no prejudices,
no partizan feeling of any kind. It is
exactly because Hecuba is nothing to
us that her sorrows are such an
admirable motive for a tragedy. I do
not know anything in the whole
history of literature sadder than the
artistic career of Charles Reade. He wrote one
beautiful book, "The Cloister and the
Hearth," a book as much above "Romola"
as "Romola" is above 'Daniel Deronda",
and the wasted the rest of his life in a foolish
attempt to be modern, to draw public
attention to the state of our convict
prisons, and the management of our private
lunatic asylums. Charles Dickens
was bad depressing enough in all conscience when
he tried to arouse our sympathy for
the victims of the poor-law administration;,
but Charles Reade, an artist, a scholar, a man
with a true sense of beauty, raging and
roaring over the abuses of modern contemporary
life like a common pamphleteer, or
a sensational journalist, is really a
sight for the angels to weep over.
